Expectation1: Providing spiritual guidance and counseling to community members
Situation1: A community member casually mentioned wanting advice whenever the imam has free time.
Expectation2: Follow laws and respect others’ rights and public property
Situation2: Late-evening music plans overlap with the building’s quiet hours while a neighbor’s windows are open.
Story: As an imam, I am always ready to offer spiritual guidance to anyone in need. This evening, after Maghrib prayer, Brother Karim approached me, mentioning he’d like to talk about some personal struggles—“whenever you have free time, Imam.” I assured him I’d make time soon. Later, as a citizen and resident of this apartment building, I remembered my friends and I had planned a small music session in my living room. We’d been looking forward to it all week, but I realized our gathering would start just as the building’s quiet hours began. I glanced out my window and saw my neighbor, Mrs. Lee, enjoying the cool air with her windows wide open. I felt the weight of my dual responsibilities: as an imam, I should be available for Brother Karim, but as a citizen, I must respect the building’s rules and my neighbors’ peace. The thought of disappointing my friends, neglecting a community member, or disturbing Mrs. Lee all pressed on me at once. My mind raced, torn between the expectations of my faith and my civic duty, unsure which path to take.
